text:
S-X2
289. Rice, Alice Blanche (Mrs. Edgar H.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: R.I.C.E. MRS. A.B.
Address: 856 EAST 7TH AVE
Birthplace: LONDON ENGLAND

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1889
Where did you set up housekeeping? MANOTICK
Where had you been living before that? TORONTO ONTARIO
For how many people did you prepare meals? FAMILY OF 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 MILES
How often could a visit be made to the store? MONTHLY
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? SUGAR, ROLLED OATS, TEA, CORN MEAL, YEAST

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? RED FIFE
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 LBS. EACH
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? MORE
Whole wheat flour? MORE
Was flour milled locally? YES
How far away? 7 MILES What year? 1889
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? BREAD
Cornmeal? YES
Whole Wheat? NO
Farina? NO
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? NO
How did you grind it? NO
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: R.I.C.E. Mrs. A.B. THAKE
Address: 8516 EAST ZTAKE

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1920
Where did you set up housekeeping? Montana
Where had you been living before that? Montana
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? Monthly
How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, rolled oats, flour, own meal, sugar

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Red Eye
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. each
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $7.50
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole Wheat Flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.20
What other grain products did you use? Beans
Cornmeal?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 50 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwards

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 lb.

At what price? 90 cents

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Milking cows on share basis

Butter? Same manner

Eggs? Bought till having own fowl

What was the price of butter? 10 cents per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes

Did you make butter? Yes

Did you make cheese? No

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork occasionally

How did you get fresh meat? Butchering own stock

How often did you get fresh meat? Once a year

How did you preserve meat? Smoked and brine cured

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not till later years

If so what year was it organized? 1912

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Ducks, pheasants, chickens, partridges, rabbits

For how long? From 1890 to 1918

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very seldom

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned during early years then later

Kinda? Salmon and herring for spring, white fish occasionally in winter
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? $20.06

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 20 oz.

At what price? $0.90 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Did you make butter? Yes

Did you make cheese? Yes

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your meat supply in the early years?

How did you get fresh meat?

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not

If so what year was it organized? 1918

Did you use game?

For how long from 1890 to 1918

What part did fish play in the family diet?

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Was the fish bought locally from N.C. Xinda?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Bulk tea. At what price? 80 cents per lb.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.

Price? What other beverages were used? Coffee.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 25 cents per bushel.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from? Local.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1899.

Potatoes Cabbage Carrots Onions

Turnips Beets

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 100 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? 10 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Bulk.

What was the price of prunes? 10 cents per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No.

peas? No. corn? No. beans? No. Saskatoons? No.

other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1899.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1899.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? No.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? No.

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar? No.
6. VEGETABLES

What kind of tea did you buy? (Tea, coffee, etc.) ____________________________

What kind of coffee did you buy? (Beans or ground) ____________________________

What other beverages were used? ____________________________

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? _______

Could you get potatoes at the store? ____________________________

If not, where from? ____________________________

What year did you first grow your own vegetables? ____________________________

What quantities did you buy with every harvest? ____________________________

How did you buy produce? (In bulk or by the box?) ____________________________

What weight? ____________________________

How did the grocer pack it? ____________________________

What was the price of produce? ____________________________

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? ____________________________

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ____________________________

Did you can? ____________________________

Other foods? ____________________________

What year did you first preserve fruits by canning? ____________________________

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ____________________________

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ____________________________

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ____________________________

To what extent? ____________________________

Did you make your own vinegar? ____________________________

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Yes
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using hops? No
Salt rising? Yes
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1890 Hauled water from neighbor. 1893 Wells just of slough.
1911 Bore well in Saskatchewan, at 65 ft struck rock, by pond with smaller auger to 90 ft struck extreme hard layer for 4 ft. When auger passed through this layer, dropped to 120 ft. Water rose to 60 ft level which it maintained at all times.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1890 Hauled weekly from spring, 1893 Willa just off plough road, with an old oxen and yoke to go from ranch entrance and layon for 4 weeks.

When our spring flooded through this layer, chopped to Amity Road.

Water rose to 60 ft. below which it remained at all times.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ...........................................

If you made your own, did you use lye? .............. wood ashes? ..............

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? .................................

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ................................

Where did you get your fuel? ................................

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

As the areas became more settled coal became available for winter supply also financial circumstances allowed one to purchase things of this nature.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...........................................

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ..............

By whom was your first cook stove made? ................................

What year was it purchased? ...........................................

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ..............

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) .................

When did you first see enamel ware? ...........................................

Aluminum? ...........................................
13. SOAP
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?
If you made your own, did you use lye? ... wood ash?
What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days?
Where did you get your fuel?
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days?
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
By whom was your first cook stove made?
What year was it purchased?
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
Then did you first use?
Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

\[
\text{Packaged food purchased from Eaton's, about 1912.}
\]

Local purchased was bought until不得已.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

\[
\begin{align*}
\text{Breakfast:} & \quad \text{Oatmeal porridge, eggs, toast, milk.} \\
\text{Dinner:} & \quad \text{Garden vegetables, roast beef or pork, potatoes.} \\
\text{Supper:} & \quad \text{Homemade soup, pie.}
\end{align*}
\]

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

\[
\begin{align*}
\text{Roast chicken, garden vegetables, apple & mince pies.} \\
\text{Mrs. Garry (age 32 years).} \\
\text{Helen, Mrs. & Mr. Rice, Miss Wilson, William} \\
\text{Age 3 years.}
\end{align*}
\]

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

First years where all lean years subsistence was partly dependent on what could be produce on the farm from 1910 to 1913 before we were able to accumulate sufficient to be able to turn some into cash to purchase other necessities. Meat was obtained in exchange for work along with other varieties of food that could be spared by others.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates when applicable).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ____________

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Miss Alice Blanche Rice
Mrs. Edgar H. Rice
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

All foods had to be prepared by hand methods, all meats were home cured, local field beans etc., where home prepared & bottled for future use.

When today one can go to the local grocer and obtain all the luxuries, the rigors from meal to meal if one cared to do so.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1918 and then to no great extent.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

At the later part of the season when cash was available an order was placed with Eaton's of Winnipeg and sufficient was ordered for the year's supply.

All clothing and wearing apparel was ordered in the same manner.

Leather goods such as harness, foot wear etc. likewise.

Garden seeds, flowers and and such was also obtained by this manner.

This continued till the town built up and carried these articles in stock.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

All foods had to be prepared by hand or stove, all meats were home grown, canned, or preserved, and all vegetables were grown and canned at home.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

1918

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

At the first year of the season no cash was available
but rather over $500 worth of clothing and supplies
were received for the year's supplies.
All clothing and necessary supplies were ready in the spring
for the coming year.
Clothing goods such as flannel, cotton, etc., blankets,
garden seeds, flour, sugar, and steel were also obtained
by this means.
This continued till the town built up and carried
their stocks in stock.
Oxford

No. 613 S
